currentWeek.title: EVOLUTION
currentWeek.artist: Jeff Mills, Jean-Phi Dary, Prabhu Edouard
currentWeek.description: Blue Latin takes classic jazz and shakes it up with Afro-Cuban, Brazilian, and Latin-jazz vibes — all wrapped in Frisina's signature danceable style. It's the perfect soundtrack for a packed dance floor or a solo groove session at home. With standout tracks like the rework of João Donato's Naquela Base and the meditative, African-inspired Incanto, this album brings jazz right into the now.

archive.title: Blue Latin
archive.description: Blue Latin takes classic jazz and shakes it up with Afro-Cuban, Brazilian, and Latin-jazz vibes — all wrapped in Frisina's signature danceable style. It's the perfect soundtrack for a packed dance floor or a solo groove session at home. With standout tracks like the rework of João Donato's Naquela Base and the meditative, African-inspired Incanto, this album brings jazz right into the now.

archive.title: Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat
archive.description: "Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat" is a 1982 album by Indian musician Charanjit Singh that uniquely blends traditional Indian ragas with electronic disco music. Utilizing instruments like the Roland TB-303 bass synthesizer, TR-808 drum machine, and Jupiter-8 synthesizer, Singh crafted a sound that many consider a precursor to acid house music, predating the genre's rise in the late 1980s. Initially overlooked, the album gained recognition in the 21st century for its innovative fusion of classical Indian music and electronic dance rhythms.

archive.title: Eastern Sounds
archive.description: Eastern Sounds is a studio album by the jazz multi-instrumentalist and composer Yusef Lateef. It was released in April 1962 through Prestige Records. This groundbreaking album reflects Lateef's exploration of Eastern musical traditions, combining them with Western jazz idioms to create a unique sonic landscape. His innovative approach to composition and instrumentation established him as one of the pioneers in world music fusion, decades before the term was widely used.
